In the context of CSRF, by "safety" I meant serving data to  
unauthorized clients. On this note, all verbs are vulnerable unless  
designed carefully.

On May 26, 2008, at 5:56 PM, Berend de Boer wrote:

>>>>>> "Subbu" == Subbu Allamaraju <subbu@...> writes:
>
>>> Right, but that's only for non-REST sites. I.e. GET should be
>>> safe, so it doesn't matter if the URL is unguessable or not.
>
>    Subbu> Whether a GET is safe or not depends on the data.
>
>    Subbu> What exactly do you mean by a non-REST site?
>
> No. GET is idempotent, you can repeat it endlessly. A client would not
> be able to detect changes if submitted once or twice. Obviously a buy
> action or a payment action through GET will cause visible changes
> because the balance statement would have changed.
>
> -- 
> Cheers,
>
> Berend de Boer
